rows.title: Switch between two frames in tkinter?

597:
<p>Here is another simple answer, but without using classes.</p>

<pre class="lang-py s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-python"><span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> tkinter <span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> *


<span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">raise_frame</span>(<span class="hljs-params">frame</span>):
    frame.tkraise()

root = Tk()

f1 = Frame(root)
f2 = Frame(root)
f3 = Frame(root)
f4 = Frame(root)

<span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> frame <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> (f1, f2, f3, f4):
    frame.grid(row=<span class="hljs-number">0</span>, column=<span class="hljs-number">0</span>, sticky=<span class="hljs-string">'news'</span>)

Button(f1, text=<span class="hljs-string">'Go to frame 2'</span>, command=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span>:raise_frame(f2)).pack()
Label(f1, text=<span class="hljs-string">'FRAME 1'</span>).pack()

Label(f2, text=<span class="hljs-string">'FRAME 2'</span>).pack()
Button(f2, text=<span class="hljs-string">'Go to frame 3'</span>, command=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span>:raise_frame(f3)).pack()

Label(f3, text=<span class="hljs-string">'FRAME 3'</span>).pack(side=<span class="hljs-string">'left'</span>)
Button(f3, text=<span class="hljs-string">'Go to frame 4'</span>, command=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span>:raise_frame(f4)).pack(side=<span class="hljs-string">'left'</span>)

Label(f4, text=<span class="hljs-string">'FRAME 4'</span>).pack()
Button(f4, text=<span class="hljs-string">'Goto to frame 1'</span>, command=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span>:raise_frame(f1)).pack()

raise_frame(f1)
root.mainloop()
</code></pre>

<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note</strong>: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7546050/switch-between-two-frames-in-tkinter/49325719#comment103814940_49325719">According to JDN96</a>, the answer below may cause a <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14408521/perl-tk-memory-leak-when-using-destroy-command">memory leak</a> by repeatedly destroying and recreating frames. However, I have not tested to verify this myself.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>One way to switch frames in <code>tkinter</code> is to destroy the old frame then replace it with your new frame.</p>
<p>I have modified <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/7557028/3357935">Bryan Oakley's</a> answer to destroy the old frame before replacing it. As an added bonus, this eliminates the need for a <code>container</code> object and allows you to use any generic <code>Frame</code> class.</p>
<pre class="lang-python s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-python"><span class="hljs-comment"># Multi-frame tkinter application v2.3</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> tkinter <span class="hljs-keyword">as</span> tk

<span class="hljs-keyword">class</span> <span class="hljs-title class_">SampleApp</span>(tk.Tk):
    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">__init__</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self</span>):
        tk.Tk.__init__(self)
        self._frame = <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>
        self.switch_frame(StartPage)

    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">switch_frame</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self, frame_class</span>):
        <span class="hljs-string">"""Destroys current frame and replaces it with a new one."""</span>
        new_frame = frame_class(self)
        <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> self._frame <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">not</span> <span class="hljs-literal">None</span>:
            self._frame.destroy()
        self._frame = new_frame
        self._frame.pack()

<span class="hljs-keyword">class</span> <span class="hljs-title class_">StartPage</span>(tk.Frame):
    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">__init__</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self, master</span>):
        tk.Frame.__init__(self, master)
        tk.Label(self, text=<span class="hljs-string">"This is the start page"</span>).pack(side=<span class="hljs-string">"top"</span>, fill=<span class="hljs-string">"x"</span>, pady=<span class="hljs-number">10</span>)
        tk.Button(self, text=<span class="hljs-string">"Open page one"</span>,
                  command=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span>: master.switch_frame(PageOne)).pack()
        tk.Button(self, text=<span class="hljs-string">"Open page two"</span>,
                  command=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span>: master.switch_frame(PageTwo)).pack()

<span class="hljs-keyword">class</span> <span class="hljs-title class_">PageOne</span>(tk.Frame):
    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">__init__</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self, master</span>):
        tk.Frame.__init__(self, master)
        tk.Label(self, text=<span class="hljs-string">"This is page one"</span>).pack(side=<span class="hljs-string">"top"</span>, fill=<span class="hljs-string">"x"</span>, pady=<span class="hljs-number">10</span>)
        tk.Button(self, text=<span class="hljs-string">"Return to start page"</span>,
                  command=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span>: master.switch_frame(StartPage)).pack()

<span class="hljs-keyword">class</span> <span class="hljs-title class_">PageTwo</span>(tk.Frame):
    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">__init__</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self, master</span>):
        tk.Frame.__init__(self, master)
        tk.Label(self, text=<span class="hljs-string">"This is page two"</span>).pack(side=<span class="hljs-string">"top"</span>, fill=<span class="hljs-string">"x"</span>, pady=<span class="hljs-number">10</span>)
        tk.Button(self, text=<span class="hljs-string">"Return to start page"</span>,
                  command=<span class="hljs-keyword">lambda</span>: master.switch_frame(StartPage)).pack()

<span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> __name__ == <span class="hljs-string">"__main__"</span>:
    app = SampleApp()
    app.mainloop()
</code></pre>
<p><a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/TTUxb.png" rel="noreferrer"><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/TTUxb.png" alt="Start page"></a> <a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/jqkOn.png" rel="noreferrer"><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/jqkOn.png" alt="Page one"></a> <a href="https://i.stack.imgur.com/DKDqA.png" rel="noreferrer"><img src="https://i.stack.imgur.com/DKDqA.png" alt="Page two"></a></p>
<h3>Explanation</h3>
<p><code>switch_frame()</code> works by accepting any Class object that implements <a href="http://effbot.org/tkinterbook/frame.htm" rel="noreferrer"><code>Frame</code></a>. The function then creates a new frame to replace the old one.</p>
<ul>
<li>Deletes old <code>_frame</code> if it exists, then replaces it with the new frame.</li>
<li>Other frames added with <code>.pack()</code>, such as menubars, will be unaffected.</li>
<li>Can be used with any class that implements <code>tkinter.Frame</code>.</li>
<li>Window automatically resizes to fit new content</li>
</ul>
<h3>Version History</h3>
<pre class="lang-none s-code-block"><code>v2.3

- Pack buttons and labels as they are initialized

v2.2

- Initialize `_frame` as `None`.
- Check if `_frame` is `None` before calling `.destroy()`.

v2.1.1

- Remove type-hinting for backwards compatibility with Python 3.4.

v2.1

- Add type-hinting for `frame_class`.

v2.0

- Remove extraneous `container` frame.
    - Application now works with any generic `tkinter.frame` instance.
- Remove `controller` argument from frame classes.
    - Frame switching is now done with `master.switch_frame()`.

v1.6

- Check if frame attribute exists before destroying it.
- Use `switch_frame()` to set first frame.

v1.5

  - Revert 'Initialize new `_frame` after old `_frame` is destroyed'.
      - Initializing the frame before calling `.destroy()` results
        in a smoother visual transition.

v1.4

- Pack frames in `switch_frame()`.
- Initialize new `_frame` after old `_frame` is destroyed.
    - Remove `new_frame` variable.

v1.3

- Rename `parent` to `master` for consistency with base `Frame` class.

v1.2

- Remove `main()` function.

v1.1

- Rename `frame` to `_frame`.
    - Naming implies variable should be private.
- Create new frame before destroying old frame.

v1.0

- Initial version.
</code></pre>

<p>Perhaps a more intuitive solution would be to hide/unhide frames using the <code>pack_forget</code> method if you are using the <code>pack</code> geometry manager.</p>
<p>Here's a simple example.</p>
<pre class="lang-py s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-python"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> tkinter <span class="hljs-keyword">as</span> tk


<span class="hljs-keyword">class</span> <span class="hljs-title class_">App</span>:
    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">__init__</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self, root=<span class="hljs-literal">None</span></span>):
        self.root = root
        self.frame = tk.Frame(self.root)
        self.frame.pack()
        tk.Label(self.frame, text=<span class="hljs-string">'Main page'</span>).pack()
        tk.Button(self.frame, text=<span class="hljs-string">'Go to Page 1'</span>,
                  command=self.make_page_1).pack()
        self.page_1 = Page_1(master=self.root, app=self)

    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">main_page</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self</span>):
        self.frame.pack()

    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">make_page_1</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self</span>):
        self.frame.pack_forget()
        self.page_1.start_page()


<span class="hljs-keyword">class</span> <span class="hljs-title class_">Page_1</span>:
    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">__init__</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self, master=<span class="hljs-literal">None</span>, app=<span class="hljs-literal">None</span></span>):
        self.master = master
        self.app = app
        self.frame = tk.Frame(self.master)
        tk.Label(self.frame, text=<span class="hljs-string">'Page 1'</span>).pack()
        tk.Button(self.frame, text=<span class="hljs-string">'Go back'</span>, command=self.go_back).pack()

    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">start_page</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self</span>):
        self.frame.pack()

    <span class="hljs-keyword">def</span> <span class="hljs-title function_">go_back</span>(<span class="hljs-params">self</span>):
        self.frame.pack_forget()
        self.app.main_page()


<span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> __name__ == <span class="hljs-string">'__main__'</span>:
    root = tk.Tk()
    app = App(root)
    root.mainloop()

</code></pre>
